newsitem.title: UK: UK's Clarke "sympathises" with Euro currecny.
newsitem.headline: UK's Clarke "sympathises" with Euro currecny.

text.p: Finance minister Kenneth Clarke on Wednesday expressed sympathy for a single European currency and accused anti-European members of the ruling Conservatives of wrecking Britain's negotiating position on the matter.

Chancellor of the Exchequer Clarke, opening a two-day parliamentary debate on the European Union, ran into jeers from fellow Conservatives when he told them jettisoning the pound sterling would not mean joining a European superstate.
Prime Minister John Major's Conservatives are bitterly divided over the single currency, which the European Union plans to introduce from 1999.
Clarke said Britain was right to keep its options open on whether or not to join economic and monetary union (EMU).
"I have made it quite clear that I am sympathetic to the idea of economic and monetary union," Clarke said.
"Whatever we decide, whether in or out, EMU will affect us. British interest lies in staying involved and making sure that Britain's interests are protected and advanced."

Clarke, widely believed to be ready to resign if Major gives way to right-wing pressure over the single currency, said the government's freedom to opt in or out of monetary union was the envy of several of the other 15 EU member states.
Major has resisted strong pressure from back-benchers to declare now that Britain would never acquiesce in what they regard as a serious undermining of national sovereignty.

The debate is being staged ahead of a European Union summit meeting in Dublin this weekend, and follows persistent demands by some Conservative MPs for the government to rule out British membership of a single currency for the next five years.
Addressing his remarks chiefly to vociferous opponents on his own side of the house, Clarke said he was as opposed as any Conservative to the creation of a European "superstate".
"Treating the debate about EMU as if it were a debate about the creation of a superstate arouses public fears and deprives the public of sensible information about the issues," he said.
"In my view there are fewer and fewer people on the continent who see EMU as a tool for further political integration."

Commenting on current European discussions on a "stability pact" that could impose fines on countries within monetary union which ran up excessive budget deficits, Clarke said it was vital that the single currency -- or euro -- zone was properly set up.
"No stability pact -- no matter how strict, no matter how dire the punishment for transgressions -- could hold such a euro zone together," he said.
Clarke said he would probably favour Britain joining a single European currency if the advantages outweighed the disadvantages, but it was too soon to determine where the balance lay.
The opposition Labour party, which is well ahead of the Conservatives in opinion polls, said joining a single currency would not end Britain's freedom in other areas such as taxation.
"I do not accept that that removes our freedom to make decisions on taxation and other issues in this House of Commons," finance spokesman Gordon Brown said during the debate.
